Win rates are a terrible indicator of balance and not even remotely an indicator of good or bad design.

Whether a design is good or bad is all opinion.  I for one like the design of Zed, Fizz, and Lee even though I don't play them (except on ARAM).

For winrates, it is a **VERY GOOD** indicator of whether a champion is balanced.  For a game like League, the perfect balance is if every champion has a winrate at 50%.  But since that will never be possible, you can tell if a champion is balanced if their winrate is as close to 50% as possible.

If they are higher than 55%, it means that they are extremely strong for whatever reason (ie easy to play, mobility, cc, overall power, tankiness, etc).  If they are lower than 45%, that show that champion sucks balls.

Fizz had a 51% win rate consistency before the 5.2 patch, now he dropped to 45-46%, that shows he's very weak **FOR NOW**.  Maybe he'll go back to 50% in a week or so when people find different builds for him.  But as of right now, he's not looking good.

Average win rates don't mean anything.
The average winrates are under influence of the skillcap and skillfloor of every champion and how high the percentage is of players that main the specific champion.
For example:
A high percentage of players that main a specific champion? Then the champion could be balanced while having a 53% win rate.

> [{quoted}](name=balbraaksel,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=0efs1qu4,comment-id=000600000000000000000001,timestamp=2015-01-31T23:58:48.553+0000)
>
> Average win rates don't mean anything.
> The average winrates are under influence of the skillcap and skillfloor of every champion and how high the percentage is of players that main the specific champion.
> For example:
> A high percentage of players that main a specific champion? Then the champion could be balanced while having a 53% win rate.

There are also way more things that go into win rates than just that. One of the simplest is how familiar the opposing players are with playing against a given champion. There are so many confounding variables in a match that win rate indicates almost nothing concrete. Not to mention, it's a fallacy that 50% win rate means perfect balance in the first place, and win rate tells absolutely nothing about whether a champion's design is good or bad.

Your first line indicates your cluelessness. Your thinking that a 50% win rate means perfect balance is just further evidence.

The problem with people who argue against win rates is that they generally come with the candid "win rates are not a good measure" response yet do not actually have any data to back up their response. Its like discrediting someone with no tangible evidence to support your claim while the other person has at least one form of data to go by.

Just because you have data doesn't mean it's valuable. I don't have to offer an alternative measurement of balance to tell you that win rates are a bad one (which they are). People who quote win rates like they're worth the time it takes to read them need to learn something about experiment design.
